description: From Middle English bitter, bittre, from Old English bitter, biter (“bitter”), from Proto-West Germanic *bit(t)r, from Proto-Germanic *bitraz (“bitter”), equivalent to bite +‎ -er (agent noun suffix) used attributively. Compare Saterland Frisian bitter (“bitter”), West Frisian bitter (“bitter”), Dutch bitter (“bitter”), Low German bitter (“bitter”), German bitter (“bitter”), Swedish bitter (“bitter”), Icelandic bitur (“bitter”).

adjectives.description: bitter (comparative bitterer or more bitter, superlative bitterest or most bitter)

entries.meaning: Having an acrid taste (usually from a basic substance).

examples: It was at the end of February, […] when the world was cold, and a bitter wind howled down the moors […].
I've been bitter ever since that defeat.

entries.meaning: (usually in the plural bitters) A liquid or powder, made from bitter herbs, used in mixed drinks or as a tonic.
examples: Thus I begin: "All is not gold that glitters,
"Pleasure seems sweet, but proves a glass of bitters.

entries.meaning: A type of beer heavily flavored with hops.
(nautical) A turn of a cable about the bitts.

verbs.description: bitter (third-person singular simple present bitters, present participle bittering, simple past and past participle bittered)

entries.meaning: (computing, informal, in combination) A hardware system whose architecture is based around units of the specified number of bits (binary digits).
examples: However, 16-bitters are far more expensive than the 8-bit variety. And, unfortunately, have only a handful of business applications software packages that really take advantage of them.
